newsitem.title: FRANCE: France to pay for calf slaughter in mad cow crisis.
newsitem.headline: France to pay for calf slaughter in mad cow crisis.

text.p: France offered on Tuesday to pay farmers to let calves be slaughtered and made into animal feed in a scheme to prop up markets hit by the mad cow crisis and overproduction of beef.

"This is one of the first measures to control production of beef and thereby contribute to bringing markets back into balance," the Agriculture Ministry said, euphemistically calling the slaughter a "transformation process".

A statement said farmers would be paid 798.5 francs ($156) for each calf up to 20 days old they decided to have "transformed". Slaughtered calves would end up as feed for other farm animals such as pigs and chickens, officials said.
The French meat office OFIVAL said France was the third European Union nation, after Britain and Portugal, to introduce such a slaughter, removing the calves from markets for human consumption.
The agriculture ministry says it is illegal to feed the slaughtered calves' meat to cows and other ruminants, but it is allowed in the case of omnivores.

France was the first foreign country to ban imports of British beef in March after London said there might be a link between mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) and its human equivalent, Creutzfeldt-Jacob Disease (CJD).
Britain is by far the nation hardest hit by mad cow disease.
But beef consumption fell sharply around the world after the announcement.
OFIVAL, in charge of carrying out the slaughter, said the measures were mainly aimed at cutting the numbers of male calves born of dairy cows.
The ministry set no limit on the size of the slaughter. France has an estimated four million dairy cows and more than four million calves. ($1=5.1330 francs)
